transcripts.text: Good afternoon, good evening, good morning, depending on where you are.  This is Catania Alvin from London.  Thank you to subscribers.  Thank you to the commenters.  Very interesting points.  I haven't had a chance to reply for the last few days.  There's been a lot on.  This is Sir Bill Cash with his wonderful knowledge and common sense.  I'm not so impressed with the interviewer, however.  This is an interview in the Houses of Parliament.

Well, first of all, she said I think it's 110 times that she wasn't able to extend.  That's the first point.  The second thing is to get quite clear that motions in the House of Commons are not the same as acts of Parliament.  And I've written to Donald Tusk advising him that there is very likely to be a legal challenge to the way in which the government is going about all this for a very simple reason.  The government cannot exercise its powers to frustrate the intentions of Parliament.
And that's what is happening.

The intentions of Parliament were made absolutely clear, and that, by the way, applies to international treaties as well.  And the reality is that the two acts of Parliament in particular are the Notification of Withdrawal Act and also the Withdrawal Act itself.  The Withdrawal Act contains the repeal of the European Community Act 1972 from exit day.  Now, the fact that Exit Day may be extended doesn't make any difference to the main legislative intention and the main legislative effect, because the repeal of the 1972 Act, which applies to all the laws,  etc.,  are all bundled together, and
that

goes in lockstep with the Exit Day itself.  But the Parliament has made its views clear.  The House of Commons has made its view clear.  It doesn't want no deal at all.  And the Yvette Cooper bill passed saying to the Prime Minister, please go and ask for a delay.  Well, so what?
I love that.  So what?  You know, this is it.  These reporters haven't got their heads around things.

Because actually it doesn't have any... In the end, trying to get something through Parliament when the House of Commons doesn't agree, is it very difficult for a government?  It may look like it, but the reality is that a motion is not the same as something that has legal effects.  That is the key issue.  We've been through this several times over the last few months.  But it feels like you're going against the tide of opinion in the House of Commons.
She's stuck on opinion and he's coming from a knowledge of what is lawful.

what has standing in the sense that how do you get bills through parliament if you don't have backing in the house of commons for it.  well the bottom line is that for example we're going to have the withdrawal and implementation bill to follow any withdrawal agreement if it gets through which i don't think it will.  but the reality is that all these pieces of legislation are what make acts of Parliament.  That is the rule of law.  The law of the land is quite clear.  The law of the land is that we are leaving the European Union and that is set out in what's called Section 1 and a withdrawal act.  It couldn't be clearer.  The reality is that tonight...
No, she's saying the reality is that tonight she can't hear him.  She can't grasp that there is something called the law of the land.  It's a dangerous hoot, really.

It will be very much certain that we won't be leaving on Friday.  Whatever you say, and I understand that you're saying that about the law as it stands, the reality is we didn't leave on the 29th of March and we're not going to leave on Friday.  Well, thank you.  I understand what you're trying to say.  kind of territory, and I'm not talking idly about a likely challenge in the courts.  There are very, very distinguished and preeminent lawyers involved in the analysis that I've sent to Donald Tusk.  They will notice that if they make this decision, and in particular if they impose conditions, because that would really magnify the degree of unlawfulness.  So there we are, and in addition to that, at a more practical note as well, This is very practical law, but I'm talking about the amount of money concerned.  Every time they make an extension, for example, if they offer an extension or suggest a suggestion for one year, that is another £12 billion for the British taxpayer.
Good Lord, who's brought that up?  £12 billion for the taxpayer, British taxpayer, every time they ask for an extension.  I mean, really?

But you know what many will say to you, if you'd voted for Theresa May's deal, we would have left on the 29th of March, we would have left last week.  Is there a part of you worried that actually you might have blown the chances of Brexit happening at all?

Does this interviewer have any real idea what Theresa May's so-called deal, which actually is a treaty, and what it tied... Britain into, even closer into Europe than the present situation, this woman.  She doesn't know what she's talking about.  So, now on to the next.  Now, here I've got up, the brilliant Lord Lily blows the lid off the Brexit debacle.
Do you think the Prime Minister is wasting her time with these questions?
That was the Brady Agreement for an invisible border.
In Europe.  Sue.
She's not acting with the people of Great Britain's interests at her heart.  She's deceiving them.  And many other people are doing the same in her coterie.

Would you have us leave without a deal on April the 1st?  in place after many deals with us.  The plane can fly, the Norwich will get licences and so on.  The facilities are available at Palais, and they're basically short of free flow, and free flow are traffic.  So there's nothing serious to see at this point.  It doesn't mean, as I said before, that we have a free trade agreement with the Minister of Order in Ireland and Ireland.  If we don't have that fine, it's probably more than someone else's.  If we go ahead and leave, it's the law of law.  I interviewed the governor of the Bank of England this week and he says that people of that view, they should forget the fiction and that it was absolute nonsense that that could be a solution.
Listen to what he has to say about Carney.  Well, he disagrees with his predecessor, Mervyn King.

His predecessor was Mervyn King.  He said the opposite.  I mean, I don't know.  I mean, things are rather better than that.  Mr.  Carney has been all over the place, and he's been making projections that he's had to reverse and remake upon.  So you think that we could come out on April the 12th and revert to WTO rules?  I'm just trying to understand how you see this working and how you see this working in a way that is not disorderly.  I don't know if it's on the cable.

Exactly.  There's been demonisation by the BBC, by the newspapers, by various people in Parliament, like Yvette Cooper.  Many people have been damning it.  Have a wonderful day, everyone.  God bless.  This is Catania Alvin signing out.  Bye-bye.
